page.title: Introduction
page.contents:
This professional development module is part of a suite of related resources. The suite includes the following resources:

  • Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction: Issue Brief
    This issue brief presents a broad overview of digital literacy as it relates to adult learners in English language acquisition programs. It is intended to serve as an introduction to the topic of digital literacy that teachers and administrators can use as a springboard to additional in-depth resources.

  • Integrating Digital Literacy Into English Language Instruction: Companion Learning Resource

  • This digital magazine is a practical, comprehensive instructional resource written specifically for teachers. It provides numerous examples of instructional models, strategies, tools, and tasks for integrating digital literacy into English language instruction.

The issue brief and companion learning resource can be found at

https://lincs.ed.gov/programs/eslpro

page.title: Definition of Digital Literacy
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-4.mp3

Audio transcript


Digital literacy includes a wide range of skills associated with using technology to enable users to find, evaluate, organize, create, and communicate information, including using basic digital skills in meaningful ways. It also means having the skills, strategies, and dispositions to use those skills to solve problems in increasingly technology-rich environments. These skills are important for participation in 21st century life, including education, work, and community.

  • The term digital literacy means the skills associated with using technology to enable users to find, evaluate, organize, create, and communicate information (U.S. Department of Education, 2015).

  • Digital literacy also means the ability to use those skills to solve problems in the increasingly technology-rich environments of 21st century life (Leu, Kinzer, Coiro, Castek, & Henry, 2013).

page.title: Welcome
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-5.mp3

Audio transcript


Welcome to Unit 2. This unit is part of an online module on integrating digital literacy into adult English language instruction. The four units in this professional development module parallel the definition of digital literacy introduced on the previous slide.

Unit 1 focuses on basic digital literacy skills, the importance of digital literacy, and ways to integrate digital literacy meaningfully into instruction. It is a good idea to start with Unit 1 and then move to any of the other units. Unit 2 focuses on information and communication technologies and the ways that creating and communicating information digitally also promotes English language learning. Unit 3 looks at digital information literacy and how to help students learn to find, understand, and critically evaluate information on the Internet. Unit 4 incorporates a wide range of digital literacies into problem-solving in technology-rich environments and is for teachers who have already been integrating digital literacy into their practice and want to take it further.

By participating in this unit, teachers, professional developers, and administrators can learn how to use information and communication technologies to enhance opportunities for their adult English language learning students to increase their English language acquisition and their digital literacy skills at the same time.

Welcome to Unit 2 of the module on Integrating Digital Literacy Into Adult English Language Instruction

Unit 1: Digital Literacy in Our lives

Unit 2: Information and Communication Technologies for Language Learning

Unit 3: Digital Information Literacy

Unit 4: Solving Problems in Technology-Rich Environments

While this unit can be done on its own, it is best if you first do Unit 1, “Digital Literacy in Our Lives.”

This unit focuses on ways to integrate technology to both increase language learning and to develop digital literacy, with an emphasis on listening, speaking, reading, writing, and vocabulary in English language acquisition.

page.title: Important Points to Remember About Digital Literacy
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-6.mp3

Audio transcript


In Unit 1, you heard some things about digital literacy that have significant implications for English language instruction. These important points are to remind you about takeaways from Unit 1 that serve as the foundation for this unit.

First, it is common for English language learners, or ELLs—and their teachers—to have a variety of experiences with technology and a variety of digital skills.

Second, because technology is always evolving, everyone is a learner regarding technology.

Third, effective approaches take advantage of what individuals in the group already know and do.

Fourth, with technology the teacher is a facilitator and co-learner rather than an expert.

Fifth, adult ELLs, like most adults, learn basic digital skills better when the tasks are embedded in meaningful, contextualized classroom activities.

Sixth, ELLs can learn language skills through digital tasks and learn digital skills through language tasks.

Finally, adult ELLs may acquire digital skills more effectively through hands-on discovery learning while in pursuit of a meaningful goal than through receiving formal teaching of isolated skills.

  • It is common for English language learners (ELLs)—and their teachers—to have a variety of experiences with technology and a variety of digital skills.

  • Because technology is always evolving, everyone is a learner when it comes to technology.

  • Effective approaches take advantage of what individuals in the group already know and do.

  • With technology, the teacher is a facilitator and co-learner rather than an expert.

  • Adult ELLs, like most adults, learn basic digital skills better when the tasks are embedded in meaningful, contextualized classroom activities.

  • ELLs can learn language skills through digital tasks and learn digital skills through language tasks.

  • Digital skills may be more effectively acquired through hands-on discovery learning while in pursuit of a meaningful goal than through formal teaching of isolated skills, even at very low levels.

page.title: Why is Digital Literacy Important to Adult English Language Learners?
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-7.mp3

Audio transcript


As you saw in Unit 1, there are many reasons why digital literacy is important to adult ELLs. They include being ready for the workforce, advancing one’s career, being able to participate in education and training, being able to support one’s children’s education, being involved in the community, staying connected with loved ones, and creating new social networks.

There are many reasons why digital literacy is important to adult ELLs. A few reasons are:

  • workforce readiness,

  • career advancement,

  • education and training,

  • children’s education,

  • community involvement,

  • staying connected with loved ones, and

  • creating new social networks.

page.title: Organization of This Unit
page.contents:
Listen to audio:

ELL_Mod2_U2_Slide-8.mp3

Audio transcript


This unit is organized so that, first, you focus on yourself and the way that you do (or do not) use technology to perform a variety of functions in your own life. From this point, the focus is on these same functions in the lives of English language learners as well as functions in their English language acquisition.

This unit will present five different activities, one in each of five major areas: listening, speaking, reading, writing, and vocabulary. You will go through all five sections. In each section, there is an optional exploration activity to build familiarity with a technology or resource. Once you have completed the five areas, you will select one activity that you will actually engage in and report on in this unit. The activities differ regarding student level and experience with technology as well as skill area.

Part 1: “Focus on the Teacher”

Reflect on your own digital literacy skills.

Part 2: “Focus on the Students: English Language Acquisition”

Five activities, plus optional explorations:

    • Listening
    • Speaking
    • Reading
    • Writing
    • Vocabulary learning

Part 3: “Integrate Digital Tasks”

Final activity: Report on the activity you design to integrate digital literacy into your class, starting with one skill.

page.title: Digital Literacy and English Language Acquisition
page.contents:
Adult ELLs in English language acquisition programs have a wide variety of experience with technology. Among other things, they vary in

  • digital literacy in languages in which they are proficient,

  • experience with technology in English, and

  • skills with print literacy.

A student’s experience with technology is influenced by

  • education,

  • age,

  • income,

  • access to the Internet,

  • access to devices,

  • social networks,

  • family members’ use of technology, and

  • perceived relevance.
